case_vignette: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of abdominal pain, loose, non-bloody stools, and intermittent nausea. He also reports intermittent fever. He has not had vomiting, tenesmus, or rectal pain. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Rectal exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,200/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 44 mm/h. Test of the stool for occult blood and stool studies for infection are negative. A CT scan of the abdomen shows mural thickening and surrounding fat stranding of discrete regions of the terminal ileum and transverse colon. A colonoscopy is performed and biopsy specimens of the affected areas of the colon are taken.
question: Which  findings is most specific for this patient's most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing abdominal pain, loose stools, intermittent nausea, and intermittent fever for the past three weeks.
How old are you and what is your gender?
I am a 22-year-old man.
Have you recently traveled or eaten anything unusual before these symptoms started?
No, I have not traveled recently or eaten anything unusual.
Do you have any other chronic illnesses or are you on any medications?
No, I have no history of serious illness and I take no medications.
Has anyone in your family had similar symptoms or gastrointestinal issues?
No, no one in my family has had similar symptoms or gastrointestinal issues.
Have you noticed any blood in your stools or significant changes in stool color?
No, I have not noticed any blood in my stools, and there have been no significant changes in stool color.
Final Diagnosis: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
